header.title: The Scroll of Set
header.category: Western Esotericism, Occultism, Setianism, Organizational Communications

central_thesis: The Scroll of Set (Issue Number 2, October 1975) functions as a foundational communication for the nascent Temple of Set, articulating its philosophical distinctiveness regarding individual advancement and degree systems, particularly in contrast to its Church of Satan origins, while providing critical administrative updates, fostering community engagement through regional publications, and hinting at core Setian texts and symbols for its membership.

structure_content.chapter_title: [1] The Book of Coming Forth by Night: Historical Commentary
structure_content.summary: This section announces an article by Michael A. Aquino V° on the historical commentary of 'The Book of Coming Forth by Night', directing readers to 'The Ruby Tablet of Set' for the most current edition.
Presents a philosophical aphorism by Goethe: 'As soon as you trust yourself, you will know how to live'.

Lists and briefly describes various regional and intra-Temple publications (Cavernus, Straight From Hell, Children of the Night, The Magic Cat, Voice of the Dragon), detailing their editors, locations, and general content scope, emphasizing local news and serious articles relevant to Setians. It also includes instructions for subscription inquiries and fees.

structure_content.chapter_title: [4] What is the Temple of Set?
structure_content.summary: Refers readers to the 'Temple's Membership Informational Letter' for the most current edition of an article by Michael A. Aquino V° explaining the organization.

Explains the Temple of Set's approach to degree elevations (III° and IV°), positioning itself as 'cleaning the house' of the Church of Satan by rectifying the previous system's 'near-rigidity and court favoritism'. It asserts that degrees are now based on thorough individual assessment and expertise, conferred when deserved, promising no more 'flurries' of corrections.

Stuart Munro II° reviews two books: 'Dogs of War' by Frederick Forsyth, noted for its relevance to armed insurrection and Setian philosophy, and 'Supernature' by Dr. Lyall Watson, praised for its scientific exploration of the 'supernatural' and its cohesive view of the universe, recommended for all Setians.
Mentions translations of hieroglyphs in 'The Book of Coming Forth by Night' and refers to 'The Ruby Tablet of Set' for these translations.
Provides a practical tip for members: applying clear enamel to protect pentagrams from scratches.

An editorial section thanking members for suggestions, addressing content priorities (background on 'Book of Coming Forth by Night' and Temple of Set over longer papers), discussing proposed features like a forum, letters-to-the-editor, and artwork submissions, and advising members on how to handle membership number discrepancies and address changes.

Addresses delays in shipping pentagram pendants and membership cards due to postal service issues, explaining the new distribution method via III°+ officials. It also announces the cost for extra pendants and solicits interest in smaller pentagrams (1/2" to 1") for various uses.

Details for the First National Conclave of the Temple of Set, to be held on November 1, 1975, in Santa Barbara, California. Information includes registration deadlines, dinner pricing (with a 15% surcharge), the banquet/conference schedule (7-9 p.m.) with a midnight ritual, and suggestions for daytime activities and discussion topics. Members are directed to Magistra Lilith Sinclair for registration packets.

key_concepts.definition: A nascent esoteric organization, founded in 1975, aiming to establish a distinct philosophical and practical path separate from its origins in the Church of Satan.

A hierarchical system within the Temple of Set, emphasizing individual assessment and demonstrated expertise for advancement, explicitly reformed from the 'court favoritism' of previous organizations.

The overarching philosophical and spiritual tradition espoused by the Temple of Set, characterized by a focus on individual self-trust, intellectual inquiry, and a unique approach to esoteric principles as indicated by recommended texts and internal discourse.

key_concepts.term: Book of Coming Forth by Night
key_concepts.definition: A foundational, internal text of the Temple of Set, referenced multiple times as a source of historical commentary and hieroglyphic translations.
A significant symbol or tool for Setians, issued as pendants to members, requiring care and maintenance.
Another foundational text within the Temple of Set, serving as a reference for updated editions and translations.

practical_system.description: The Temple of Set's practical system, as outlined in this early newsletter, is primarily an organizational and philosophical framework for individual self-initiation and advancement rather than a grimoire of specific magical operations. It emphasizes a rigorous, individualized assessment for progression through a structured degree system (III°, IV°), ensuring meritocracy over 'court favoritism'. The system relies heavily on internal communication channels (The Scroll of Set, regional publications) for disseminating information and fostering community. Foundational texts like 'The Book of Coming Forth by Night' and 'The Ruby Tablet of Set' are central to study and understanding the Setian current. Membership includes symbols like the pentagram, signifying affiliation and personal focus. The system encourages intellectual engagement, as seen in book recommendations spanning esoteric philosophy and scientific inquiry, and provides opportunities for communal gathering and ritual (National Conclave) to reinforce collective identity and shared purpose.
tools: Foundational texts (e.g., 'The Book of Coming Forth by Night', 'The Ruby Tablet of Set')
Regional publications (for study, communication, and networking)
rituals: A ritual will be held at midnight during the First National Conclave in Santa Barbara.

relevant_quotes.text: As soon as you trust yourself, you will know how to live - Goethe.

The Temple of Set, whether it likes it or not, has been faced with "cleaning the house" of the Church of Satan in certain matters. One of these is the degree system, which, as most of you know, had degenerated into near-rigidity and court favoritism.
For the Temple of Set, it has been and will be - a question of assessing the individual thoroughly and recognizing his or her expertise as properly due.

Dogs of War by Frederick Forsyth is a great novel. It is also a remarkable handbook if you're considering armed insurrection, gun-running, a coup d'etat or just financial shenanigans in Europe. Forsyth is a Setian, and it comes through in his philosophy.

A book that would be of benefit to all Setians is Supernature by Dr. Lyall Watson, published by Coronet. It is subtitled, “The natural history of the supernatural”, and the 350 references - all scientific and technical papers - are worth the price of the book alone. Watson is a noted biologist, and he asks questions I've heard few other scientific people ask. However not only does he deal with many of the scientifically taboo subjects, he weaves the whole universe into an incredibly cohesive unity. Quite remarkable.

critical_analysis.relevance: This document is highly relevant for understanding the foundational period of the Temple of Set. It explicitly details the organization's self-perception and its stated intent to differentiate itself from the Church of Satan, particularly regarding hierarchical advancement. It provides primary source insight into early administrative challenges, communication strategies, and the intellectual and philosophical currents guiding the nascent movement. For scholars of modern occultism and new religious movements, it offers a direct window into the early establishment of a significant esoteric order.
critical_analysis.target_audience: The primary target audience is the membership of the Temple of Set, serving as an official communication channel. A secondary audience includes scholars of Western Esotericism, modern occultism, and new religious movements, as well as practitioners interested in the historical development and early philosophy of Setianism.
